). Most patients are incidentally diagnosed with elevated hemoglobin on laboratory studies. Presenting symptoms may include fatigue, headache, generalized pruritus that often worsens after bathing, erythromelalgia (a burning sensation in the palms and soles), hypertension, and arterial/venous thrombosis. On physical examination, patients may have plethora and splenomegaly. Twenty percent of patients have arterial or venous thrombosis as their initial symptom. Bone marrow biopsy shows hypercellular marrow with erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic hyperplasia. Treatment of PV is required at diagnosis. In addition to receiving antiplatelet and other stroke prevention therapy, if PV is confirmed in this patient, he will have to undergo phlebotomy to normalize his hematocrit concentration (goal <45%). He will also need treatment with the myelosuppressive agent hydroxyurea to decrease thrombotic events.

Many different paraneoplastic syndromes may be seen in patients with renal cell carcinoma, including erythrocytosis, anemia, hepatic dysfunction in the absence of liver metastases (known as Stauffer syndrome), fever, hypercalcemia, amyloid A (secondary) amyloidosis, thrombocytosis, and polymyalgia rheumatica. Polycythemia is associated with renal cell carcinoma in 1% to 2% of cases and is a result of increased erythropoietin production. Renal cell carcinoma is not a likely cause of leukocytosis, thrombocythemia, and pruritus.

Most causes of secondary erythrocytosis share the mechanism of an elevated erythropoietin level, which is most commonly driven by hypoxemia. Polycythemia may be the presenting symptom of undiagnosed sleep apnea, and all patients with polycythemia should be screened for symptoms and signs of sleep apnea.
